The **economy of Serbia** is a developing upper-middle income economy. Its
tertiary sector accounts for two-thirds of total gross domestic product (GDP).
Serbia's nominal GDP is estimated to reach $92 billion in 2025, with a GDP per
capita of $14,175. It's purchasing power parity (PPP) stood at $216.22
billion, which amounts to $33,115 per capita. Their capital city and financial
centre is Belgrade, with Novi Sad and Niš being important economic hubs. The
Belgrade Waterfront is adjacent to the National Bank of Serbia and the
Belgrade Stock Exchange.

Serbia has a significant industrial and manufacturing base, focused mainly on
machinery, automotive manufacturing, energy, and mining. Core exports of the
Serbian economy include automobiles, base metals, furniture, food processing,
machinery, chemicals, tires, clothes, and pharmaceuticals. Highly dependent on
international trade in Europe, key trading partners include its neighbors
around Central Europe as well as China and Russia.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Serbia is classified as a developing upper-middle income economy, indicating a transitional stage with moderate to high income levels.
• The tertiary sector, encompassing services, constitutes approximately two-thirds of Serbia's total gross domestic product (GDP), highlighting the dominance of service industries in the economy.
• Serbia's nominal GDP is projected to reach $92 billion by the year 2025, reflecting anticipated economic growth.
• The GDP per capita in Serbia is estimated at $14,175, providing a measure of average economic output per person.
• Serbia's purchasing power parity (PPP) GDP stood at $216.22 billion, which translates to a PPP per capita of $33,115, indicating the relative domestic purchasing power of its citizens.
• Belgrade serves as Serbia's capital city and primary financial centre, playing a central role in the country's economic activities.
• Novi Sad and Niš are recognized as significant economic hubs within Serbia, contributing to regional economic development.

• The Belgrade Waterfront, a major urban development project, is located adjacent to the National Bank of Serbia and the Belgrade Stock Exchange, symbolizing the integration of financial institutions and urban growth.
• Serbia possesses a substantial industrial and manufacturing sector, with key focuses on machinery production, automotive manufacturing, energy generation, and mining operations.

• The core export commodities of Serbia include automobiles, base metals, furniture, food processing products, machinery, chemicals, tires, clothing, and pharmaceuticals, demonstrating a diversified export portfolio.
• Serbia's economy is highly dependent on international trade within Europe, emphasizing the importance of regional economic integration.
• Key trading partners for Serbia encompass neighboring countries in Central Europe, as well as major global economies such as China and Russia, reflecting a broad international trade network.

text:
In the decades leading up to World War I, GDP growth in Serbia grew by 0.28%
per annum. This was a slower growth rate than Northwestern Europe, leading to
a widening economic divergence between Serbia and Western Europe. Prior to
WWI, there was extensive growth in Serbia's dominant agricultural sector.
However, industrial and service sectors remained small.

In the late 1980s, at the beginning of the process of economic transition from
a planned economy to a market economy, Serbia's economy had a favorable
position in comparison to most of the Eastern Bloc countries, but it was
gravely impacted by poor economic decision-making in the 1990s, the Yugoslav
Wars, and UN sanctions and trade embargo during the 1990s. At the same time,
the country experienced a serious "brain drain". There was a severe recession
which continued until 1999. After the overthrow of Slobodan Milošević in 2000,
Serbia went through a process of transition to a market-based economy and
experienced sustained economic growth. During that period, the Serbian economy
grew 4-5% annually, average wages quadrupled, and economic and social
opportunities dramatically improved. During the Great Recession, Serbia marked
a decline in its economy of 3.1% in 2009, and following years of economic
stagnation pre-crisis level of GDP was reached only in 2016.

Since 2014, the country has been in the process of accession negotiations to
join the European Union.
openai_summarised_points: • In the decades preceding World War I, Serbia's GDP growth rate was 0.28% per annum, which was slower than that of Northwestern Europe, resulting in a widening economic divergence between Serbia and Western Europe.
• Prior to World War I, Serbia experienced extensive growth in its dominant agricultural sector, while its industrial and service sectors remained relatively small.
• In the late 1980s, at the onset of economic transition from a planned economy to a market economy, Serbia's economy was favorably positioned compared to most Eastern Bloc countries.
• During the 1990s, Serbia's economy was severely impacted by poor economic decision-making, the Yugoslav Wars, and United Nations sanctions and trade embargoes.
• Concurrently, Serbia experienced a significant "brain drain," with many skilled individuals leaving the country.
• The Serbian economy underwent a severe recession that persisted until 1999.
• Following the overthrow of Slobodan Milošević in 2000, Serbia embarked on a transition to a market-based economy, resulting in sustained economic growth.
• During the post-2000 transition period, Serbia's economy grew at an annual rate of 4-5%, average wages quadrupled, and economic and social opportunities improved dramatically.
• In 2009, during the Great Recession, Serbia's economy contracted by 3.1%.
• After several years of economic stagnation, Serbia only returned to its pre-crisis GDP level in 2016.
• Since 2014, Serbia has been engaged in accession negotiations to join the European Union.

The Serbian economy is expected to grow to $116 billion in 2029, slightly
outpacing the rest of the former Yugoslav Republics according to the IMF. It's
economy has been the largest former Yugoslav by purchasing power parity (PPP)
since 2008 and the second-largest by nominal GDP since 1998. Serbia's debt-to-
GDP ratio is currently at 41.7%, which is lower than the 60% level defined by
the Maastricht criteria as the upper limit of an acceptable level. It's
sovereign debt level is projected to be the second-lowest among the former
Yugoslav Republics by 2029, with an expected decrease from the current 49% to
46% of GDP. The average growth of Serbia's GDP from 2020 to 2025 was 4% per
year.

GDP structure by sector is: services 67.9%, industry 26.1%, agriculture 6.0%.

GDP - composition, by end use

investment in fixed capital: 18.5% (2017 est.)

investment in inventories: 2% (2017 est.)

openai_summarised_points: • The Serbian economy is projected to reach a value of $116 billion by the year 2029, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), indicating a growth rate that slightly surpasses that of other former Yugoslav Republics.
• Since 2008, Serbia has held the position as the largest economy among the former Yugoslav Republics when measured by purchasing power parity (PPP).
• By nominal GDP, Serbia has been the second-largest economy among the former Yugoslav Republics since 1998.
• Serbia's current debt-to-GDP ratio stands at 41.7%, which is notably below the Maastricht criteria threshold of 60%, considered the upper limit for an acceptable debt level.
• The country's sovereign debt level is forecasted to be the second-lowest among the former Yugoslav Republics by 2029, with a projected reduction from the current 49% to 46% of GDP.
• The average annual GDP growth rate for Serbia from 2020 to 2025 is estimated at 4%.
• The GDP structure by sector in Serbia is composed of 67.9% services, 26.1% industry, and 6.0% agriculture.

• The GDP composition by end use in 2017 was as follows: household consumption accounted for 78.2%, government consumption for 10.1%, investment in fixed capital for 18.5%, investment in inventories for 2%, exports of goods and services for 52.5%, and imports of goods and services represented -61.3%.
• Between 2000 and 2008, Serbia's public debt relative to GDP decreased significantly by 140.1 percentage points, reflecting a major reduction in debt burden during this period.
• After 2008, Serbia's public debt began to increase again as the government took measures to combat the effects of the global financial crisis that started in 2008.
• In 2018, Serbia's public debt was recorded at 53.8% of GDP, indicating a moderate level of indebtedness relative to the size of the economy.
• Public debt in absolute terms (billions of euros) and as a share of GDP over selected years is as follows:
• In 2000, public debt was €14.17 billion, constituting 201.2% of GDP.
• By 2002, debt decreased to €13.43 billion, or 68.3% of GDP.
• In 2004, debt further declined to €11.02 billion (52.6% of GDP).
• In 2006, debt stood at €9.35 billion (35.9% of GDP).
• In 2008, debt was €8.78 billion, representing 28.3% of GDP.
• Post-crisis, debt rose to €9.85 billion (32.8% of GDP) in 2009 and continued increasing to €12.16 billion (41.8% of GDP) in 2010.
• In 2011, debt reached €14.78 billion (45.4% of GDP).
• By 2012, it increased to €17.72 billion (56.2% of GDP).
• In 2013, debt was €20.14 billion (59.6% of GDP).
• In 2014, debt rose to €22.76 billion (70.4% of GDP).
• In 2015, debt further increased to €24.81 billion (74.7% of GDP).
• In 2016, debt slightly decreased to €24.71 billion (71.9% of GDP).
• In 2017, debt was €23.21 billion (61.5% of GDP).
• In 2018, debt stood at €23.01 billion (53.8% of GDP).
• By 2021, debt increased to €29.60 billion (56.5% of GDP).
• In 2022, public debt was €30.56 billion, accounting for 52.1% of GDP.
• The source of the public debt data is the Ministry of Finance of Serbia, with archival records available as of 13 May 2018 via the Wayback Machine Public Debt Administration.

text:
1000 Serbian dinar banknote

The official currency in Serbia is the Serbian dinar and its earliest use
dates back to 1214.

Serbia historically has battled high inflation, especially during the 1980s
and 1990s. In 1992 and 1993, it experienced a period of hyperinflation which
lasted for a total of 25 months. In 1993, the monthly inflation rate stood at
a staggering 313 million percent. Since the early 2000s, the inflation rate
has stabilized and in the last couple of years a relatively low level of
inflation was recorded.

openai_summarised_points: • The official currency of Serbia is the Serbian dinar, with its earliest recorded use dating back to the year 1214.
• Serbia has historically struggled with high inflation rates, particularly during the 1980s and 1990s, culminating in a period of hyperinflation in 1992 and 1993 that lasted for 25 months.
• In 1993, Serbia experienced an extreme monthly inflation rate of 313 million percent, marking one of the most severe hyperinflation episodes in modern history.
• Since the early 2000s, Serbia’s inflation rate has stabilized significantly, with relatively low inflation levels recorded in recent years.

• Inflation rates in Serbia from 2002 to 2022 show a general downward trend with fluctuations, starting at 19.5% in 2002, decreasing to single digits by 2009, reaching as low as 1.1% in 2016 and 2020, before rising again to 15.0% in 2022.

• Exchange rates of the Serbian dinar against the US dollar (USD) and the euro (EUR) have fluctuated over the years, with data recorded annually on December 31 by the World Bank and the National Bank of Serbia.
• The USD to RSD exchange rate ranged from 58.98 in 2002 to a peak of 117.13 in 2016, with values such as 62.90 (2008), 79.28 (2010), 99.46 (2014), and 110.48 (2022).
• The EUR to RSD exchange rate increased from 61.51 in 2002 to values around 117 in recent years, with notable figures including 88.60 (2008), 105.50 (2010), 120.96 (2014), and 117.67 (2022).

• The data on inflation and exchange rates reflect Serbia’s economic stabilization efforts post-hyperinflation and the ongoing challenges in maintaining currency stability amid regional and global economic conditions.

text:
Fiat 500L – motor vehicles are the leading export product of Serbia

Serbia has a wide range of free trade agreements with foreign countries and
trading blocs.

Serbia signed a free trade agreement with the European Union in 2008 enabling
exports of all products originating from Serbia without customs and other
fees. For a limited number of products (baby beef, sugar, and wine), annual
import quotas remain in effect. As of 2016, the EU countries were the largest
trading partners of Serbia with 64.4% of country's total foreign trade.

Serbia signed the CEFTA, which allows exports of all products originating from
Serbia without customs and other fees to the neighbouring countries: Albania,
Bosnia and Herzegovina, North Macedonia, Moldova, Montenegro and Kosovo. In
2016, the CEFTA countries were the second largest trading partners of Serbia.

Serbia signed a free trade agreement with EFTA members (Switzerland, Norway,
Iceland) in 2009.

The Serbian free-trade agreement with Russia was implemented since 2000; for a
limited number of products, annual import quotas remain in effect. Free-trade
agreement with Turkey has been implemented since 2010. Trade with the United
States is pursued under the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) with a
preferential duty-free entry for approximately 4,650 products.

Serbia signed a free trade agreement with China in October 2023, after six
years of negotiations.

openai_summarised_points: • Motor vehicles, exemplified by the Fiat 500L, constitute the leading export product of Serbia, highlighting the significance of the automotive sector in the country's external trade.

• Serbia maintains an extensive network of free trade agreements with various foreign countries and trading blocs, facilitating the reduction or elimination of customs duties and other trade barriers.

• In 2008, Serbia signed a free trade agreement with the European Union (EU), which allows the export of all products originating from Serbia to EU member states without customs and other fees; however, annual import quotas remain in effect for a limited number of products, specifically baby beef, sugar, and wine.

• As of 2016, EU countries represented the largest trading partners of Serbia, accounting for 64.4% of the country's total foreign trade, underscoring the EU's dominant role in Serbia's trade relations.

• Serbia is a member of the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA), which permits duty-free exports of all Serbian-origin products to neighboring countries including Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, North Macedonia, Moldova, Montenegro, and Kosovo; in 2016, CEFTA countries were Serbia's second largest trading partners.
• In 2009, Serbia signed a free trade agreement with the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) members, specifically Switzerland, Norway, and Iceland, further broadening its trade partnerships.
• Serbia's free trade agreement with Russia has been in effect since 2000, allowing duty-free trade for most products, though annual import quotas apply to a limited number of goods.
• The free trade agreement with Turkey has been operational since 2010, enhancing bilateral trade relations between Serbia and Turkey.

• Trade relations with the United States are governed by the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP), which grants Serbia preferential duty-free entry for approximately 4,650 products, facilitating access to the US market.

• After six years of negotiations, Serbia signed a free trade agreement with China in October 2023, marking a significant development in Serbia's external trade policy and expanding its access to the Chinese market.

• Serbia's export values have shown substantial growth over the years, increasing from 1,558 million USD in 2000 to 30,934 million USD in 2023, reflecting the expansion and diversification of its export sector.
• Import values have also risen significantly, from 5,614 million USD in 2000 to 39,837 million USD in 2023, indicating increased demand for foreign goods and inputs.

• The trade balance has consistently been negative throughout the period from 2000 to 2023, with deficits ranging from -1,772 million USD in 2000 to -8,903 million USD in 2023, demonstrating that imports have exceeded exports annually.

• The ratio of exports to imports (expressed as a percentage) has varied over the years, starting at 46.8% in 2000, dipping to a low of 32.8% in 2004, and improving to 77.7% by 2023, indicating a gradual narrowing of the trade gap relative to imports.

• Notable fluctuations in trade figures occurred during the period, such as a peak export value of 25,563 million USD in 2021 and the highest import value of 41,154 million USD in 2022, reflecting dynamic trade activities influenced by global and regional economic conditions.
• The data presented are sourced from the Statistical Office of Serbia, ensuring official and reliable statistical information on Serbia’s external trade performance from 2000 through 2023.

text:
Attracting foreign direct investments is set as a priority for the government
of Serbia, which provides both financial and tax incentives to companies
willing to invest. Leading investor nations in Serbia include: Germany, Italy,
United States, China, Austria, Norway, and Greece. Majority of FDI went into
automotive industry, food and beverage industry, machinery, textile and
clothing. Foreign direct investments (FDI) coming from the EU accounted for
more than 63% of total FDI coming to Serbia from the period of 2010 until
2021.

Blue-chip corporations making investments in manufacturing sector include:
Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, Bosch, Michelin, Siemens, Panasonic, Continental,
Schneider Electric, Philip Morris, LafargeHolcim, PepsiCo, Coca-Cola,
Carlsberg and others. In the energy sector, Russian energy giants, Lukoil and
Gazprom have made large investments. In metallurgy sector, Chinese steel and
copper giants, Hesteel and Zijin Mining have acquired steel mill in Smederevo
and copper mining complex in Bor, respectively. The financial sector has
attracted investments from Italian banks such as Intesa Sanpaolo and
UniCredit, Crédit Agricole and Société Générale from France, Erste Bank and
Raiffeisen from Austria, among others. ICT and telecommunications saw
investments from likes such as Microsoft, Telenor, Telekom Austria, and NCR.
In retail sector, biggest foreign investors are Dutch Ahold Delhaize, German
Metro AG and Schwarz Gruppe, Greek Veropoulos, and Croatian Fortenova.

openai_summarised_points: • The government of Serbia prioritizes attracting foreign direct investments (FDI) and offers both financial and tax incentives to companies willing to invest in the country.
• Leading investor countries in Serbia include Germany, Italy, the United States, China, Austria, Norway, and Greece.
• The majority of FDI in Serbia has been directed towards the automotive industry, food and beverage industry, machinery, textile, and clothing sectors.
• From 2010 to 2021, foreign direct investments originating from the European Union accounted for more than 63% of the total FDI inflows into Serbia.

• Prominent blue-chip corporations investing in Serbia’s manufacturing sector include Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, Bosch, Michelin, Siemens, Panasonic, Continental, Schneider Electric, Philip Morris, LafargeHolcim, PepsiCo, Coca-Cola, and Carlsberg.
• In the energy sector, major Russian companies such as Lukoil and Gazprom have made significant investments in Serbia.
• The metallurgy sector has attracted Chinese steel and copper companies, with Hesteel acquiring the steel mill in Smederevo and Zijin Mining acquiring the copper mining complex in Bor.

• The financial sector in Serbia has seen investments from Italian banks Intesa Sanpaolo and UniCredit, French banks Crédit Agricole and Société Générale, and Austrian banks Erste Bank and Raiffeisen, among others.
• The ICT and telecommunications sectors have attracted investments from multinational corporations including Microsoft, Telenor, Telekom Austria, and NCR.
• In the retail sector, major foreign investors are Dutch company Ahold Delhaize, German companies Metro AG and Schwarz Gruppe, Greek company Veropoulos, and Croatian company Fortenova.
• The data on foreign direct investments in Serbia is sourced from the Development Agency of Serbia and the National Bank of Serbia.

text:
Map of motorways in Serbia. Vineyards in Fruška Gora; Serbia was the 11th
largest wine producer in Europe and 19th in the world in 2014.

Serbia has very favourable natural conditions (land and climate) for varied
agricultural production. It has 5,056,000 ha of agricultural land (0.7 ha per
capita), out of which 3,294,000 ha is arable land (0.45 ha per capita). In
2024, Serbia exported agricultural and food products worth $5.3 billion.
Agricultural exports constitute more than one-fifth of all Serbia's sales on
the world market. Serbia is one of the largest provider of frozen fruit to the
EU (largest to the French market, and second largest to the German market).
Agricultural production is most prominent in Vojvodina on the fertile
Pannonian Plain. Other agricultural regions include Mačva, Pomoravlje,
Tamnava, Rasina, and Jablanica. In the structure of the agricultural
production 70% is from the crop field production, and 30% is from the
livestock production. Serbia is world's second largest producer of plums
(582,485 tons; second to China) and the third largest of raspberries (127,010
tons, trailing only Russia and the United States). It is also significant
producer of maize (6.48 million tons, ranked 32nd in the world) and wheat
(2.07 million tons, ranked 35th in the world). Other important agricultural
products are: sunflower, sugar beet, soybean, potato, apple, mutton, pork
meat, beef, poultry and dairy.

There are 56,000 ha of vineyards in Serbia, producing about 230 million litres
of wine annually. Most famous viticulture regions are located in Vojvodina and
Šumadija.
openai_summarised_points: • Serbia possesses highly favourable natural conditions, including land and climate, conducive to diverse agricultural production, with a total of 5,056,000 hectares of agricultural land, equating to 0.7 hectares per capita, of which 3,294,000 hectares is arable land, or 0.45 hectares per capita.
• In 2024, Serbia exported agricultural and food products valued at $5.3 billion, with agricultural exports accounting for more than 20% of the country's total sales on the global market.
• Serbia is a major supplier of frozen fruit to the European Union, being the largest provider to the French market and the second largest to the German market.

• The most prominent agricultural production occurs in the Vojvodina region, situated on the fertile Pannonian Plain; other significant agricultural regions include Mačva, Pomoravlje, Tamnava, Rasina, and Jablanica.
• The composition of Serbia’s agricultural production consists of approximately 70% crop field production and 30% livestock production.
• Serbia ranks as the world’s second largest producer of plums, producing 582,485 tons, second only to China.
• It is the third largest global producer of raspberries, with an output of 127,010 tons, following Russia and the United States.
• Serbia is also a significant producer of maize, yielding 6.48 million tons and ranked 32nd worldwide, and wheat, producing 2.07 million tons and ranked 35th globally.
• Other important agricultural products in Serbia include sunflower, sugar beet, soybean, potato, apple, mutton, pork meat, beef, poultry, and dairy products.
• Serbia has 56,000 hectares of vineyards, which produce approximately 230 million litres of wine annually.
• The most renowned viticulture regions in Serbia are located in Vojvodina and Šumadija.
• In 2014, Serbia was the 11th largest wine producer in Europe and ranked 19th in the world.

text:
Đerdap 1 hydroelectric power station

The energy sector is one of the largest and most important sectors to the
country's economy. Serbia is a net exporter of electricity and importer of key
fuels (such as oil and gas).

Serbia has an abundance of coal, and significant reserves of oil and gas.
Serbia's proven reserves of 5.5 billion tons of coal lignite are the 5th
largest in the world (second in Europe, after Germany). Coal is found in two
large deposits: Kolubara (4 billion tons of reserves) and Kostolac (1.5
billion tons). Despite being small on a world scale, Serbia's oil and gas
resources (77.4 million tons of oil equivalent and 48.1 billion cubic meters,
respectively) have a certain regional importance since they are largest in the
region of former Yugoslavia as well as the Balkans (excluding Romania). Almost
90% of the discovered oil and gas are to be found in Banat and those oil and
gas fields are by size among the largest in the Pannonian basin but are
average on a European scale.

The production of electricity in 2018 in Serbia was 38.3 billion kilowatt-
hours (KWh), while the final electricity consumption amounted to 28.1 billion
kilowatt-hours (KWh). Most of the electricity produced comes from thermal-
power plants (71% of all electricity) and to a lesser degree from
hydroelectric-power plants (24%) and wind energy (3%). There are 6 lignite-
operated thermal-power plants with an installed power of 3,936 MW; largest of
which are 1,502 MW-Nikola Tesla 1 and 1,160 MW-Nikola Tesla 2, both in
Obrenovac. Total installed power of 9 hydroelectric-power plants is 2,831 MW,
largest of which is Đerdap 1 with capacity of 1,026 MW. In addition to this,
there are mazute and gas-operated thermal-power plants with an installed power
of 353 MW. The entire production of electricity is concentrated in
Elektroprivreda Srbije (EPS), public electric-utility power company.

The current oil production in Serbia amounts to over 1.1 million tons of oil
equivalent and satisfies some 43% of country's needs while the rest is
imported. National petrol company, Naftna Industrija Srbije (NIS), was
acquired in 2008 by Gazprom Neft. The company's refinery in Pančevo (capacity
of 4.8 million tons) is one of the most modern oil-refineries in Europe; it
also operates network of 334 filling stations in Serbia (74% of domestic
market) and additional 36 stations in Bosnia and Herzegovina, 31 in Bulgaria,
and 28 in Romania. There are 155 kilometers of crude oil pipelines connecting
Pančevo and Novi Sad refineries as a part of trans-national Adria oil
pipeline.

Serbia is heavily dependent on foreign sources of natural gas, with only 17%
coming from domestic production (totalling 491 million cubic meters in 2012)
and the rest is imported, mainly from Russia (via gas pipelines that run
through Ukraine and Hungary). Srbijagas, public company, operates the natural
gas transportation system which comprise 3,177 kilometers of trunk and
regional natural gas pipelines and a 450 million cubic meter underground gas
storage facility at Banatski Dvor.

The industry is the economy sector that was the hardest hit by the UN
sanctions and trade embargo and NATO bombing during the 1990s and transition
to market economy during the 2000s. The industrial output saw dramatic
downsizing: in 2013 it was expected to be only a half of that of 1989. Main
industrial sectors include: automotive, mining, non-ferrous metals, food-
processing, electronics, pharmaceuticals, clothes. Serbia has 14 free economic
zones as of September 2017, in which many foreign direct investments are
realized.

Automotive industry (with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles as a forebearer) is
dominated by cluster located in Kragujevac and its vicinity, and contributes
to export with about $2 billion. Country is a leading steel producer in the
wider region of South Central Europe and had production of nearly 2 million
tons of raw steel in 2018, coming entirely from Smederevo steel mill, owned by
the Chinese Hesteel.

Serbia notably manufactures intel smartphones named Tesla smartphones.

Food industry is well known both regionally and internationally and is one of
the strong points of the economy. Some of the international brand-names
established production in Serbia: PepsiCo and Nestlé in food-processing
sector; Coca-Cola (Belgrade), Heineken (Novi Sad) and Carlsberg (Bačka
Palanka) in beverage industry; Nordzucker in sugar industry. Serbia's
electronics industry had its peak in the 1980s and the industry today is only
a third of what it was back then, but has witnessed a something of revival in
last decade with investments of companies such as Siemens (wind turbines) in
Subotica, Panasonic (lighting devices) in Svilajnac, and Gorenje (electrical
home appliances) in Valjevo. The pharmaceutical industry in Serbia comprises a
dozen manufacturers of generic drugs, of which Hemofarm in Vršac and Galenika
in Belgrade, account for 80% of production volume. Domestic production meets
over 60% of the local demand.
openai_summarised_points: • The industry sector in Serbia was severely impacted during the 1990s by UN sanctions, trade embargoes, and NATO bombing, followed by challenges during the transition to a market economy in the 2000s, resulting in a dramatic downsizing of industrial output; by 2013, industrial output was expected to be only half of that in 1989.
• Key industrial sectors in Serbia include automotive, mining, non-ferrous metals, food-processing, electronics, pharmaceuticals, and clothing.
• As of September 2017, Serbia had established 14 free economic zones, which have attracted numerous foreign direct investments.

• The automotive industry is a major sector, led by Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, with a dominant industrial cluster located in Kragujevac and its surrounding area, contributing approximately $2 billion to Serbia’s exports.

• Serbia is a leading steel producer in the South Central Europe region, producing nearly 2 million tons of raw steel in 2018, all sourced from the Smederevo steel mill, which is owned by the Chinese company Hesteel.
• Serbia manufactures Tesla-branded smartphones, notable for being Intel-based devices.

• The food industry in Serbia is recognized both regionally and internationally as a strong economic sector, with several major international companies establishing production facilities in the country.
• Prominent international brands in Serbia’s food-processing sector include PepsiCo and Nestlé.
• In the beverage industry, international companies such as Coca-Cola (based in Belgrade), Heineken (Novi Sad), and Carlsberg (Bačka Palanka) have established production operations.
• Nordzucker operates in Serbia’s sugar industry, contributing to the sector’s development.

• Serbia’s electronics industry peaked in the 1980s but had declined to about one-third of its former size; however, it has experienced a partial revival in the last decade due to investments by companies such as Siemens (wind turbines in Subotica), Panasonic (lighting devices in Svilajnac), and Gorenje (electrical home appliances in Valjevo).

• The pharmaceutical industry in Serbia consists of approximately a dozen manufacturers specializing in generic drugs, with Hemofarm (located in Vršac) and Galenika (based in Belgrade) producing 80% of the country’s pharmaceutical output.
• Domestic pharmaceutical production in Serbia satisfies over 60% of the local market demand.

text:
Serbia's mining industry is comparatively strong: Serbia is the 18th largest
producer of coal (7th in Europe) extracted from large deposits in Kolubara and
Kostolac basins; it is also world's 23rd largest (3rd in Europe) producer of
copper which is extracted by Zijin Bor Copper, a large copper mining company,
acquired by Chinese Zijin Mining in 2018; significant gold extraction is
developed around Majdanpek.
openai_summarised_points: • Serbia's mining industry is relatively strong on a global and European scale, reflecting its significant role in the extraction of key minerals.
• Serbia ranks as the 18th largest coal producer worldwide and holds the 7th position in Europe for coal production.
• The primary coal deposits in Serbia are located in the Kolubara and Kostolac basins, which serve as major sources for coal extraction.
• In copper production, Serbia is the 23rd largest producer globally and the 3rd largest producer in Europe.
• Copper mining in Serbia is primarily conducted by Zijin Bor Copper, a major copper mining company.
• Zijin Bor Copper was acquired by the Chinese company Zijin Mining in 2018, marking significant foreign investment in Serbia's mining sector.
• Serbia also has notable gold extraction activities centered around the Majdanpek area, highlighting the diversity of its mining industry.

text:
Fixed telephone lines connect 89% of households in Serbia, and with about 8.82
million users the number of cellphones surpasses the total population of
Serbia by 25%. The largest mobile operator is Telekom Srbija with 4.06 million
subscribers, followed by Yettel Serbia with 2.73 million users and A1 Srbija
with about 2.03 million. Some 58% of households have fixed-line (non-mobile)
broadband Internet connection while 67% are provided with pay television
services (i.e. 38% cable television, 17% IPTV, and 10% satellite). Digital
television transition has been completed in 2015 with DVB-T2 standard for
signal transmission.

205 meters-high Avala Tower, 2010

The Serbian IT industry is rapidly growing and changing pace. In 2018, IT
services exports reached $1.3 billion. With 6,924 companies in the IT sector
(2013 data[update]), Belgrade is one of the information technology centers in
this part of Europe, with strong growth. Microsoft Development Center located
in Belgrade was at the time of its establishment fifth such center in the
world. Many world IT companies choose Belgrade as regional or European center
such as Asus, Intel, Dell, Huawei, NCR, Ubisoft, etc. These companies have
taken advantage of Serbia's large pool of engineers and relatively low wages.

Large investments by global tech companies, such as Microsoft, typical of the
2000s, are being eclipsed by a growing number of domestic startups which
obtain funding from domestic and international investors. What brought
companies like Microsoft in the first place was a large pool of talented
engineers and mathematicians. In just the first quarter of 2016, more than
US$65 million has been raised by Serbian startups including $45 million for
Seven Bridges (a Bioinformatics firm) and $14 million for Vast (a data
analysis firm). One of the most successful startups have been Nordeus, which
was founded in Belgrade in 2010, and is one of Europe's fastest-growing
companies in the field of video games (the developer of Top Eleven Football
Manager; a game played by over 20 million people).
openai_summarised_points: • Fixed telephone lines connect 89% of households in Serbia, indicating widespread access to traditional telecommunication infrastructure.
• The number of cellphone users in Serbia is approximately 8.82 million, surpassing the total population by 25%, reflecting high mobile penetration.
• Telekom Srbija is the largest mobile operator in Serbia with 4.06 million subscribers, followed by Yettel Serbia with 2.73 million users and A1 Srbija with about 2.03 million subscribers.
• Approximately 58% of Serbian households have fixed-line (non-mobile) broadband Internet connections, demonstrating significant internet accessibility.
• Pay television services are available to 67% of households, distributed as 38% cable television, 17% IPTV, and 10% satellite television.
• Serbia completed its digital television transition in 2015, adopting the DVB-T2 standard for signal transmission, marking a modernization of broadcast technology.
• The Avala Tower, standing 205 meters high, is a notable telecommunications landmark in Serbia, with a referenced image from 2010.
• The Serbian IT industry is experiencing rapid growth and transformation, with IT services exports reaching $1.3 billion in 2018.
• As of 2013, there were 6,924 companies operating in Serbia’s IT sector, highlighting the sector’s size and economic significance.
• Belgrade is recognized as a major information technology center in the region, exhibiting strong growth and attracting international companies.
• The Microsoft Development Center in Belgrade was the fifth such center globally at the time of its establishment, underscoring Serbia’s importance in Microsoft’s global operations.

• Major global IT companies such as Asus, Intel, Dell, Huawei, NCR, and Ubisoft have established regional or European centers in Belgrade, leveraging Serbia’s large pool of engineers and relatively low wages.
• While large investments by global tech companies characterized the 2000s, the current trend shows a rise in domestic startups securing funding from both domestic and international investors.
• The initial attraction for companies like Microsoft was Serbia’s large pool of talented engineers and mathematicians, which continues to support the IT sector’s growth.

• In the first quarter of 2016 alone, Serbian startups raised over US$65 million in funding, including $45 million for Seven Bridges, a bioinformatics firm, and $14 million for Vast, a data analysis company.

• Nordeus, founded in Belgrade in 2010, is one of Serbia’s most successful startups and one of Europe’s fastest-growing companies in the video game industry, known for developing Top Eleven Football Manager, a game played by over 20 million people worldwide.

text:
The touristic sector accounted for 1.4% of GDP in 2017 and employs some 75,000
people, about 3% of the country's workforce. Foreign exchange earnings from
tourism in 2018 were estimated at $1.5 billion.

Serbia is not a mass-tourism destination but nevertheless has a diverse range
of touristic products. In 2018, total of over 3.4 million tourists were
recorded in accommodations, of which half were foreign.

Tourism is mainly focused on the mountains and spas of the country, which are
mostly visited by domestic tourists, as well as Belgrade which is preferred
choice of foreign tourists. The most famous mountain resorts are Kopaonik,
Stara Planina, and Zlatibor. There are also many spas in Serbia, the biggest
of which is Vrnjačka Banja, Soko Banja, and Banja Koviljača. City-break and
conference tourism is developed in Belgrade (which was visited by 938,448
foreign tourists in 2018, more than a half of all international visits to the
country) and to a lesser degree Novi Sad. Other touristic products that Serbia
offer are natural wonders like Đavolja varoš, Christian pilgrimage to the many
Orthodox monasteries across the country and the river cruising along the
Danube. There are several internationally popular music festivals held in
Serbia, such as EXIT (with 25–30,000 foreign visitors coming from 60
countries) and the Guča trumpet festival.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2017, the tourism sector in Serbia accounted for 1.4% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and employed approximately 75,000 people, representing about 3% of the national workforce.
• Foreign exchange earnings from tourism in Serbia were estimated at $1.5 billion in 2018.
• Serbia is not considered a mass-tourism destination but offers a diverse range of touristic products catering to various interests.
• In 2018, over 3.4 million tourists were recorded in Serbian accommodations, with approximately half of these tourists being foreign visitors.
• Tourism in Serbia primarily focuses on mountain resorts and spa towns, which are predominantly frequented by domestic tourists.
• Belgrade is the preferred destination for foreign tourists, serving as a hub for city-break and conference tourism.
• The most renowned mountain resorts in Serbia include Kopaonik, Stara Planina, and Zlatibor.
• Major spa towns in Serbia include Vrnjačka Banja, Soko Banja, and Banja Koviljača, which attract numerous visitors seeking wellness tourism.
• In 2018, Belgrade was visited by 938,448 foreign tourists, accounting for more than half of all international visits to Serbia.
• Novi Sad also contributes to city-break and conference tourism, though to a lesser extent than Belgrade.

• Serbia offers additional touristic attractions such as natural wonders like Đavolja Varoš, Christian pilgrimage sites including numerous Orthodox monasteries, and river cruising along the Danube River.
• The country hosts several internationally recognized music festivals, notably the EXIT festival, which attracts 25,000 to 30,000 foreign visitors from 60 countries.
• The Guča trumpet festival is another prominent cultural event drawing significant international attention.

text:
Serbia has a strategic transportation location since the country's backbone,
Morava Valley, represents by far the easiest route of land travel from
continental Europe to Asia Minor and the Near East.

Serbian road network carries the bulk of traffic in the country. Total length
of roads is 45,419 km of which 915 km are "class-Ia state roads" (i.e.
motorways); 4,481 km are "class-Ib state roads" (national roads); 10,941 km
are "class-II state roads" (regional roads) and 23,780 km are "municipal
roads". The road network, except for the most of class-Ia roads, are of
comparatively high quality to the Western European standards because of huge
financial investments Serbias has been seeing in the last 10 years.

Over 300 kilometers of new motorways has been constructed in the last decade
and additional 142 kilometers are currently under construction: A5 motorway
(from north of Kruševac to Čačak) and 30 km-long segment of A2 (between Čačak
and Požega). Coach transport is very extensive: almost every place in the
country is connected by bus, from largest cities to the villages; in addition
there are international routes (mainly to countries of Western Europe with
small Serb diaspora). Routes, both domestic and international, are served by
more than 100 bus companies, biggest of which are Lasta and Niš-Ekspres. As of
2018[update], there were 1,959,584 registered passenger cars or 1 passenger
car per 3.5 inhabitants.

Serbia has 3,819 kilometers of rail tracks, of which 1,279 are electrified and
283 kilometers are double-track railroad. The major rail hub is Belgrade (and
to a lesser degree Niš), while the most important railroads include:
Belgrade–Bar (Montenegro), Belgrade–Šid–Zagreb (Croatia)/Belgrade–Niš–Sofia
(Bulgaria) (part of Pan-European Corridor X), Belgrade–Subotica–Budapest
(Hungary) and Niš–Thessaloniki (Greece). Although still a major mode of
freight transportation, railroads face increasing problems with the
maintenance of the infrastructure and lowering speeds. The rail services are
operated by Srbija Voz (passenger transport) and Srbija Kargo (freight
transport).

There are three airports with regular passenger traffic. Belgrade Nikola Tesla
Airport served 5.6 million passengers in 2018 and is a hub of flagship carrier
Air Serbia which carried some 2.5 million passengers in 2018. Niš Constantine
the Great Airport is mainly catering low-cost airlines. Morava Airport is
currently only served by Air Serbia.

Serbia has a developed inland water transport since there are 1,716 kilometers
of navigable inland waterways (1,043 km of navigable rivers and 673 km of
navigable canals), which are almost all located in northern third of the
country. The most important inland waterway is the Danube (part of Pan-
European Corridor VII). Other navigable rivers include Sava, Tisza, Begej and
Timiş River, all of which connect Serbia with Northern and Western Europe
through the Rhine–Main–Danube Canal and North Sea route, to Central Europe via
the Tisza, Begej and Danube Black Sea routes, and to Southern Europe via the
Sava river. More than 2 million tons of cargo were transported on Serbian
rivers and canals in 2016 while the largest river ports are: Novi Sad,
Belgrade, Pančevo, Smederevo, Prahovo and Šabac.

In 2021, the labour force was estimated at 3.201 million and employment stood
at 2.848 million persons (formal employment amounted to 2.473 million while
informal was at 0.375 million). Employment rate (among population aged 15 and
over) is comparatively low and stood at 48.6%; of those employed; of those
employed 15.9 worked in agriculture, 28.1% in industry, and 56% in services in
2018. The unemployment rate has been in double digits throughout the post-
socialist era, reaching its peak at 25.9% in 2012. Since then, the rate has
decreased substantially, with the creation of new jobs in primarily private
sector, reaching 9.8% in 2021.

According to the latest monthly report of the Statistical Office of the
Republic of Serbia, the average monthly salary in January 2022 amounted to
120,085 Serbian dinars (1,022 euros) gross or 85,422 Serbian dinars (727
euros) net. The median salary amounted to 85,422 Serbian dinars (727 euros)
gross or 64,860 (552 euros) net, which means that 50% of the employees had
earned a salary up to that amount.

The employer is also liable to pay for additional social security
contributions which brings the total labour cost for the average salary to
150,107 Serbian dinars (1,280 euros), thus the total tax ratio amounts to
26.9%. The map below shows average salaries by region in December 2022,
expressed in gross terms in order to make the data comparable to the data that
is published by Eurostat. Due to the nature of Serbia's economy, the majority
of people working in Serbia work under the so-called "entrepreneurship"
salary. This category of worker is seen in local markets, for examples,
plumbers, and a variety of occupations. The majority of people working in the
IT are also entrepreneurs, and entrepreneurs' tax contribution will not exceed
the maximum amount of 10% of their salary. The average tax contribution is
from €80 to €250 a month (depending on the location registered in Serbia),
which is between 0.0042% to 2% of tax when compared to the max amount of
income allowed under the entrepreneurship bracket. This makes Serbia one of
the best countries for entrepreneurship in Europe, with lowest income tax rate
in Europe.

openai_summarised_points: • In 2021, Serbia's labour force was estimated at 3.201 million individuals, with total employment reaching 2.848 million persons; formal employment accounted for 2.473 million, while informal employment stood at 0.375 million.
• The employment rate among the population aged 15 and over was relatively low at 48.6% in 2021.
• Employment distribution by sector in 2018 was as follows: 15.9% in agriculture, 28.1% in industry, and 56% in services.
• Serbia's unemployment rate has consistently remained in double digits throughout the post-socialist period, peaking at 25.9% in 2012.
• Since 2012, the unemployment rate has significantly declined due to job creation primarily in the private sector, reaching 9.8% in 2021.

• Unemployment rates by district in 2021 were categorized by color on a map: purple districts had rates below 10%, blue districts ranged from 10% to 15%, orange districts ranged from 15% to 20%, and red districts had rates of 20% and above.

• According to the Statistical Office of the Republic of Serbia's latest monthly report, the average gross monthly salary in January 2022 was 120,085 Serbian dinars (1,022 euros), while the net average salary was 85,422 dinars (727 euros).
• The median gross salary in January 2022 was 85,422 dinars (727 euros), and the median net salary was 64,860 dinars (552 euros), indicating that 50% of employees earned up to these amounts.

• Employers are responsible for additional social security contributions, raising the total labour cost for the average salary to 150,107 Serbian dinars (1,280 euros), with a total tax ratio of 26.9%.
• A regional salary map for December 2022, expressed in gross terms for Eurostat comparability, showed variations in average salaries across Serbia.
• A significant portion of Serbia’s workforce operates under the "entrepreneurship" salary scheme, common among local trades such as plumbers and many IT professionals.
• Entrepreneurs in Serbia benefit from a tax contribution cap of 10% of their salary, with average monthly tax contributions ranging from €80 to €250 depending on the registered location.

• The entrepreneurial tax contribution corresponds to between 0.0042% and 2% of the maximum income allowed under the entrepreneurship bracket, making Serbia one of the most favorable countries in Europe for entrepreneurship due to its low income tax rates.

• A salary map for January 2025 categorized districts by gross average monthly salary: purple districts earned €1,300 and above, blue districts earned between €1,100 and €1,299, orange districts earned between €1,000 and €1,099, and red districts earned below €1,000.
